title: Enduring Understanding & Essential Knowledge Standards: Grades 9-12
subject: AP Microeconomics (2022)

document.title: AP® Microeconomics COURSE AND EXAM DESCRIPTION

CFA8A45A1B4746BC9D27C9F616DE6CBD.description:
Sources of income and wealth inequality include
differences in tax structures (progressive and
regressive tax structures), human capital, social
capital, inheritance, effects of discrimination,
access to financial markets, mobility, and
bargaining power within economic and social
units (firms, labor unions, and families).

5A1EACC4B2B143E6BB0DF5C1C9C21072.description:
Each factor of production receives the value of
its marginal product, which can contribute to
income inequality.

4A710F4CCD7E484E810B43051CEF5856.description:
Explain sources of income
and wealth inequality

538BFD907B9D4811A4380D0AD8CC0134.description:
The Lorenz curve and Gini coefficient are used to
represent the degree of inequality in distributions
and to compare distributions across different
countries, policies, or time periods.

8070A32E88204D03AF4595B799A45C83.description:
Income levels and poverty rates vary greatly
both across and within groups (e.g., age,
gender, race) and countries.

CEB387465C934F62BB61508426434E99.description:
Define measures of
economic inequality in
income and wealth.

BBC4777A408746EDA46D8DE4DA6DE3F5.description: Market outcomes can result in income inequality.

EBE4B8B53FEF4D58985C7F85E10D6E2B.description:
Governments use antitrust policy in an attempt
to make markets more competitive.

1FCAE2C28B6E46FB9D6F15F99E34C8D0.description:
A natural monopoly will require a lumpsum subsidy to produce at the allocatively
efficient quantity.

B72040168F4F4ED0B7723029E173AC9B.description:
Government can use price regulation to
address inefficiency due to monopoly.

9021636B7E044677AC63ACB467505A39.description:
Government intervention in imperfect
markets can increase efficiency if the policy
correctly addresses the incentives that led to
the market failure.

6B43355A007A43EB8B17C7F396AAAA7F.description:
Binding price ceilings and floors affect prices
and quantities differently depending on the
market structures (perfect competition,
monopoly, monopolistic competition, and
monopsony) and the price elasticities of supply
and demand.

866FC7DFD7294A7E9DB076C2055670F7.description:
Lump-sum taxes and lump-sum subsidies do
not change either marginal cost or marginal
benefit; only fixed costs will be affected.

812454B2F2084DB99D637CCD9887656E.description:
Per-unit taxes and subsidies affect the
total price consumers pay, net price firms
receive, equilibrium quantity, consumer and
producer surpluses, deadweight loss, and
government revenue or cost. The impact of
change depends on the price elasticity of
demand and supply.

C5C6A89E407B4D05AEE385C6A1BE4A92.description:
a. Define government
policy interventions in
imperfect markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
government policies can
alter market outcomes in
perfectly and imperfectly
competitive markets.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from government policies
in perfectly competitive
and imperfectly
competitive markets.

427C6E2ABC4D4AD4917A301960E40514.description: In imperfect markets, well-designed government policy can reduce waste.

468A1405E31141288EA8F0619849BBE0.description:
The Effects of Government
Intervention in Different
Market Structures

46C37F6ADCD34283B18EA06B2344D654.description:
Some natural resources are, by their nature,
non-excludable and rival and therefore
open access. Private individuals inefficiently
overconsume such resources.

95E5A212ECAE466FB6235A8673262127.description:
Due to the free rider problem, private
individuals usually lack the incentive to
produce public goods, leaving government as
the only producer.

EBB49FEF57F14813B89EBB822B8037EB.description:
Private goods are rival and excludable, and
public goods are non-rival and non-excludable.

D44C9D777BB64A3BA9739D0C9C3E2E1D.description:
a. Define whether goods are
rival and/or excludable.
b. Explain how the
nature of rival and/
or excludable goods
influences the behavior of
individuals and groups.

EC74570BCBA74DD1AB13724996E58DC2.description: Private incentives can fail to account for all socially relevant considerations.

B21C2EF2585B42D382DCC7D998F496ED.description:
Policies that address positive or negative
externalities include taxes/subsidies,
environmental regulation, public provision,
the assignment of property rights, and the
reassignment of property rights through
private transactions.

C224A5F5E5984E2E8D46981F986E4A69.description:
Explain (using graphs where
appropriate) how public
policies address positive or
negative externalities.

7A46C536BA6442EDA5DFB8E4CC7EAC4D.description:
Rational agents have the incentive to free ride
when a good is non-excludable.

AC439670BE9D4E48ADAD054B8C4EC132.description:
In the presence of externalities, rational agents
respond to private costs and benefits and not
to external costs and benefits.

3ED7D40125814D2787DF493BC813A196.description:
Externalities are either positive or negative and
arise from lack of well-defined property rights
and/or high transaction costs.

157E183AD03541AFB27CA707532542EE.description:
The socially optimal quantity of a good occurs
where the marginal social benefit of consuming
the last unit equals the marginal social cost of
producing that last unit, thus maximizing total
economic surplus.

9FD79795E45047C192A7A82B780B05EE.description:
a. Define externalities.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
how in the presence of
externalities, private
markets do not take into
consideration social costs
or social benefits.

894B7E9AF8FF4CFC84C3F8666AEDC675.description: Private incentives can fail to account for all socially relevant considerations.

536B6B8454094E56996CBABA0A2C5892.description:
Producing any non-efficient quantity results in
deadweight loss.

4CB56EDABC8F45E894ED603E71E99377.description:
Equilibrium allocations can deviate from
efficient allocations due to situations such
as monopoly; oligopoly; monopolistic
competition; negative and positive externalities
in production or consumption; asymmetric
information; and insufficient production of
public goods.

C6EFEAB2FCA340ACB67BC60E78226336.description:
a. Explain equilibrium
allocations in imperfect
markets relative to
efficient allocations
(using graphs where
appropriate) and why these
markets are inefficient.
b. Calculate (using graphs
where appropriate) the
deadweight loss resulting
from the production of a
non-efficient quantity.

067CCEA44963403AA7A9BAF6435B73DE.description:
Market inefficiencies can be eliminated by
designing policies that equate marginal social
benefit with marginal social cost.

8CE33C0486DF40849F4E63E66218E081.description:
Policymakers use cost-benefit analysis
to evaluate different actions to reduce or
eliminate market inefficiencies.

4469795CDA31489B80BEE4E47052FCB0.description:
Rational agents make optimal decisions
by equating private marginal benefits and
private marginal costs that can result in
market inefficiencies.

90ED27E51BB14A7089ABA7352AEB4A7D.description:
Rational agents can pursue private actions
to exploit or exercise market characteristics
known as market power.

C265066C0B3E455DB5DCBB4424F2872D.description:
Explain (using graphs where
appropriate) how private
incentives can lead to
actions by rational agents
that are socially undesirable
(inefficient) market outcomes.

74C3A0F9315B4102BB477D5F78954E0A.description:
The market equilibrium quantity is equal to
the socially optimal quantity only when all
social benefits and costs are internalized
by individuals in the market. Total economic
surplus is maximized at that quantity. [See also
PRD-3 and POL-3.]

15DBC62AF8F54D3D8ABA6B157434EB0F.description:
The optimal quantity of a good occurs where
the marginal benefit of consuming the last unit
equals the marginal cost of producing that last
unit, thus maximizing total economic surplus.

1F8363CC9E8B485D98C81F7D9A1983DD.description:
a. Define social efficiency.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
why resource
allocation in perfectly
competitive markets is
socially efficient.

21E443854ADE44B3AA4FB33C402E2FE1.description:
Perfectly competitive markets allocate resources efficiently, but imperfect
competition often results in market inefficiencies.

065910DEE5E44EDAB3175D69A73D7000.description:
Socially Efficient
and Inefficient
Market Outcomes

3A364FC23BE24EACB30BB92F6A9FB5CF.description:
Market
Failure and
the Role of
Government

32D6D32D33FE47C88DDE7B38BE90BB1E.description:
When a typical firm hires additional workers
in a monopsonistic labor market, the marginal
factor (resource) cost is greater than the supply
price of labor.

4F8B0F772B524376832F84FD53FAA441.description:
In a monopsonistic labor market, a typical firm
hires additional labor as long as the marginal
revenue product is greater than the marginal
factor (resource) cost (the wage of a new unit
of labor plus the wage increase given to all
existing labor).

9CD9EC1FC17E4432905A139B8A2C9C30.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of
monopsonistic markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) the
profit-maximizing behavior
of firms buying labor
(with other inputs fixed) in
monopsonistic markets.
c. Calculate (using data from
a graph or table where
appropriate) measures
representing the profitmaximizing behavior of
firms buying labor (with
other inputs fixed) in
monopsonistic markets.

673E9F0318DC4C21BF1683852CE9FD23.description:
Factor prices provide incentives and convey information to firms and factors
of production.

BC27789F410B4F76A0A1B9C92C97B601.description:
Marginal revenue product of a factor of
production is the change in total revenue
divided by the change in that factor of
production, which is also equal to the marginal
physical product of that factor multiplied by the
marginal revenue (MRP = MP × MR). Firms in a
perfectly competitive output market will have
marginal revenue product of labor that is equal
to the value of the marginal product of labor
(VMPL = MPL × P) because marginal revenue
for each unit of output is equal to price.

E2925BD1A629466892943502897877E4.description:
To minimize costs or maximize profits, firms
allocate inputs such that the last dollar spent
on each input yields the same amount of
marginal product.

6170856B985041E7AE7BE32E3A26E949.description:
A typical firm hires labor in a perfectly
competitive labor market as long as the
marginal revenue product of labor is greater
than the market wage.

6DFD36DA228A47D6BEE06259BEFA4B35.description:
In a perfectly competitive labor market, the
wage is set by the market and each firm hires
the quantity of workers, where the marginal
factor (resource) cost (wage) equals the
marginal revenue product of labor. A typical
firm may be a perfect competitor in the labor
market even if it is an imperfect competitor in
its output markets.

5F539F8150B84899B1727A93CEEFA340.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of
perfectly competitive
factor markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
the profit-maximizing
behavior of firms buying
labor (with other inputs
fixed) in perfectly
competitive markets.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
where appropriate)
measures representing
the profit-maximizing
behavior of firms buying
labor (with other inputs
fixed) in perfectly
competitive markets.

49F6217972324363999BE34810E23718.description:
Factor prices provide incentives and convey information to firms and factors
of production.

D81A4B2E8E364258A31FBD5967D74E37.description:
Profit-Maximizing
Behavior in Perfectly
Competitive
Factor Markets

FFEACD499C914C00837BE5215C8A8CF3.description:
Changes in the determinants of labor supply
(such as immigration, education, working
conditions, age distribution, availability of
alternative options, preferences for leisure, and
cultural expectations) cause the labor supply
curve to shift.

181ADE4C61EA4FA78A5CB4ECB1C0A9A1.description:
Changes in the determinants of labor demand,
such as the output price and the productivity
of the worker, cause the labor demand curve
to shift.

1911A189D5FF473A9E5E2A9C55F838F8.description:
Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) firms’
and factors’ responses
to changes in incentives
and constraints.

18BA1D60F6374743B62AF86137F5D6D5.description:
Factor prices provide incentives and convey information to firms and factors
of production.

1F87CDD5CEDD43809C1CDD08B9B2E99A.description:
Changes in Factor
Demand and
Factor Supply

5DF62487497F4C46ACE7B19E5A7B8248.description:
The quantity of labor demanded is negatively
related to the wage rate, while the quantity
of labor supplied is positively related to the
wage rate in a given labor market, other
things constant.

C0C5323937B948D5A1BF15113297A892.description:
Factors of production (labor, capital, and land)
respond to factor prices (wages, interest, and
rent), and employers’ (firms’) decision to hire is
based on the productivity of the factors, output
price, and cost of the factor.

BC28A4037C824B1EABFB23D50A7C807B.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to factor markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) the
relationship between
factors of production,
firms, and factor prices.
c. Calculate (using data from
a graph or table where
appropriate) the marginal
revenue product and
marginal resource cost.

C7887C221C9944359C872A6083A48DFD.description:
Factor prices provide incentives and convey information to firms and factors
of production.

C2E05161A59B479EA33D2FF4E5E02D94.description:
Oligopolists have difficulty achieving the
monopoly outcome for reasons similar to
those that prevent players from achieving
a cooperative outcome in the Prisoner’s
Dilemma; nevertheless, prices are generally
higher and quantities lower with oligopoly (or
duopoly) than with perfect competition.

5A3447A064464D07808418EBF753FE01.description:
A Nash equilibrium is a condition describing the
set of actions in which no player can increase
his or her payoff by unilaterally taking another
action, given the other players’ actions.

BF5938AB7AD64DBDA94E23407A457561.description:
A player has a dominant strategy when the
payoff to a particular action is always higher
independent of the action taken by the other
player.

5C656A18E5CD46ACBC2BC9AC938682BB.description:
A strategy is a complete plan of actions for
playing a game; the normal form model of a
game shows the payoffs that result from each
collection of strategies (one for each player).

69393C183BAA425C99F508E8CF205F98.description:
A game is a situation in which a number of
individuals take actions, and the payoff for
each individual depends directly on both the
individual’s own choice and the choices of
others.

D9EE2E3053924BC0BD4508A2877678E8.description:
Firms in an oligopoly have an incentive to
collude and form cartels.

95D8B26409214E158BD4D1BF2BF71BAB.description:
An oligopoly is an inefficient market structure
with high barriers to entry, where there are few
firms acting interdependently.

1F43B9CF108449E6BB1DCA68D9A3DA7D.description:
a. Define (using tables as
appropriate) key terms,
strategies, and concepts
relating to oligopolies and
simple games.
b. Explain (using tables as
appropriate) strategies
and equilibria in
simple games and the
connections to theoretical
behaviors in various
oligopoly market and
non-market settings.
c. Calculate (using tables as
appropriate) the incentive
sufficient to alter a player’s
dominant strategy.

CA61624DAE1F486D83E7D26248037B5A.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency.

732D34CC16CB4B3892F660C425137E5B.description:
In a market with monopolistic competition,
firms producing differentiated products may
earn positive, negative, or zero economic profit
in the short run. Firms typically use advertising
as a means of differentiating their product. Free
entry and exit drive profits to zero in the long
run. The output level, however, is smaller than
the output level needed to minimize average
total costs, creating excess capacity. The
price is greater than marginal cost, creating
allocative inefficiency.

5845BB58E8CB4489A232D5AD6BDB42FD.description:
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
equilibrium, firm decision
making, consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets and
why prices in imperfectly
competitive markets
cannot be relied on to
coordinate the actions
of all possible market
participants and can lead
to inefficient outputs.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
as appropriate) areas
of consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets.

99525581F4104180A5CFD32B76E7FE77.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency.

9A6CF814F8A143EABE850A2CE609339F.description:
With perfect price discrimination, a monopolist
produces the quantity where price equals
marginal cost (just as a competitive market
would) but extracts all economic surplus
associated with its product and eliminates all
deadweight loss.

0B0DC9DEED724113A38EC81D609234F5.description:
A firm with market power can engage in
price discrimination to increase its profits or
capture additional consumer surplus under
certain conditions.

6794EB3005E4402CA50C0128A5A15D3F.description:
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
equilibrium, firm decision
making, consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets and
why prices in imperfectly
competitive markets
cannot be relied on to
coordinate the actions
of all possible market
participants and can lead
to inefficient outputs.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
as appropriate) areas
of consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets.

E329E84877214BB895C3D43B7D10B43F.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency

367EDC5F80884EAAAC8DF43EFFF502A0.description:
In a natural monopoly, long-run economies
of scale for a single firm exist throughout the
entire effective demand of its product.

1AEC9FDC42B54F0B9554FBCF044A0608.description:
In a monopoly, equilibrium (profit-maximizing)
quantity is determined by equating marginal
revenue (MR) to marginal cost (MC). The price
charged is greater than the marginal cost.

87CBFF0E0E5F44E1A58251318A11E8FD.description: A monopoly exists because of barriers to entry.

0D42084FB5234DCDBF229B9ABFF62F47.description:
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
equilibrium, firm decision
making, consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets and
why prices in imperfectly
competitive markets
cannot be relied on to
coordinate the actions
of all possible market
participants and can lead
to inefficient outputs.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
as appropriate) areas
of consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets.

66543CFD388E44038ECCC27BDEBFF82C.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency

F5EFFBD0706E48CEAAA708B540C4E61C.description:
Incentives to enter an industry may be
mitigated by barriers to entry. Barriers to
entry—such as high fixed/start-up costs, legal
barriers to entry, and exclusive ownership
of key resources—can sustain imperfectly
competitive market structures.

38A2E660BFB7409282EE808C1F5A8183.description:
In imperfectly competitive markets, consumers
and producers respond to prices that are
above the marginal costs of production
and/or marginal benefits of consumption
(i.e., price is greater than marginal cost in an
inefficient market).

B60E2B818628424CB7B64659A2848ABA.description:
In imperfectly competitive output markets and
assuming all else is constant, a firm must lower
price to sell additional units.

C94A6DE47E8141DEB718B067A31B7DE1.description:
Imperfectly competitive markets include
monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic
competition in product markets and
monopsony in factor markets.

1E9B0BA12BD04DF88F07F51856A95CD6.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate)
the characteristics of
imperfectly competitive
markets and inefficiency.

22806B620A42493DA00D7906FC10444F.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency.

75B80A1DD6C24EBA8393A99BA9297711.description:
A perfectly competitive market in long-run
equilibrium is allocatively and productively
efficient.

5D7878B480164EF991F60550527F9825.description:
Firms may be in a constant cost, increasing
cost, or decreasing cost industry. Long-run
prices depend on the portion of the long-run
cost curves on which firms operate.

B2A3F55098754C54BD253E9F1DEC5574.description:
In a long-run perfectly competitive equilibrium,
productive efficiency implies all operating
firms produce at efficient scale, price equals
marginal cost and minimum average total cost,
and firms earn zero economic profit.

33E23A5DC13D438FB131039F3AEC5376.description:
In a short-run competitive equilibrium, price
can either be above or below its long-run
competitive level resulting in profits or
losses, motivating entry or exit of firms
and moving prices and quantities toward
long-run equilibrium.

40E90A18B6034BE19920A154CE71F16F.description:
At a competitive market equilibrium, the
price of a product equals both the private
marginal benefit received by the last
unit consumed and the private marginal
cost incurred to produce the last unit, thus
achieving allocative efficiency.

4A809E68F50C41A99FCF24759F9B51D2.description:
At a competitive market equilibrium, firms are
price takers and select output to maximize
profit by producing the level of output where
the marginal cost equals marginal revenue
(at the price).

AB915478817B489F9E790DCF64B80DF5.description:
In perfectly competitive markets, firms can sell
all their outputs at a constant price determined
by the market.

05B88828280549F38E035F72BEAD3273.description:
In perfectly competitive markets, prices
communicate to consumers and producers
the magnitude of others’ marginal costs
of production and marginal benefits of
consumption and provide incentives to act
on that information (i.e., price equals marginal
cost in an efficient market).

5A9D97D1AAA4476288B202FA1B5AF97B.description:
A perfectly competitive market is efficient.
Firms in perfectly competitive markets face no
barriers to entry and have no market power.

49238F79CB1C4E2A9C29BC3942D51FAC.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of
perfectly competitive
markets and efficiency.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
equilibrium and firm
decision making in
perfectly competitive
markets and how prices
in perfectly competitive
markets lead to
efficient outcomes.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) economic
profit (loss) in perfectly
competitive markets.

F3FBD00239C3486D97FE861DAFF4EF76.description:
Even with a common goal of profit-maximization, market structure constrains and
influences prices, output, and efficiency.

9C79D8E5F6EB43E6BACDA7EDE8384CD6.description:
In the absence of barriers to entry or exit, in
the long run (i.e., once factors that are fixed
in the short run become variable), firms enter
a market in which there are profit-making
opportunities and exit a market when they
anticipate economic losses.

46EF9A24AA8349EF90EE814F5AC586E5.description:
In the short run, firms decide to operate
(i.e., produce positive output) or shut down
(i.e., produce zero output) by comparing total
revenue to total variable cost or price to
average variable cost (AVC).

482E278BDB154EFCBDCFC5D56035306D.description:
Explain (using graphs or
data where appropriate)
firms’ short-run decisions
to produce positive
output levels, or long-run
decisions to enter or exit
a market in response to
profit-making opportunities.

6EBF9C4D76CE47BE89AADC03B2E86C79.description:
Firms’ short-run decisions to produce output, and long-run decisions to enter or
exit a market, are based on profitability.

A847134C8E9E447EA952B2F3F369F629.description:
Firms’ Short-Run Decisions
to Produce and Long-Run
Decisions to Enter
or Exit a Market

312689BD128E4044911A4803A767A909.description:
Firms are assumed to produce output to
maximize their profits by comparing marginal
revenue and marginal cost.

ADB63093AE9F419792179B9E090CEB1E.description:
a. Define (using graphs or
data as appropriate) the
profit-maximizing rule.
b. Explain (using a graph or
data as appropriate) the
profit-maximizing level
of production.

422D8AAF514F45AAA0EBA410C83D6787.description:
To determine the optimal level at which to pursue an activity whose total benefits
exceed total cost, rational economic agents compare marginal benefits and
marginal costs.

389498F231F346BD94D72B12E733D695.description:
Accounting profit fails to account for implicit
costs (such as cost of financial capital,
compensation for risk, or an entrepreneur’s
time), which, if fully compensated, result in
normal profit.

EC0BA8AC2A394A70B22BBA0E90A6734B.description:
Firms respond to economic profit (loss) rather
than accounting profit.

5297BB3C6387487E945813719085E794.description:
a. Define the different types
of profit.
b. Explain how firms respond
to profit opportunities.
c. Calculate a firm’s profit
or loss.

7C915F4CA952441D944B3DE147299A41.description:
To determine the optimal level at which to pursue an activity whose total benefits
exceed total cost, rational economic agents compare marginal benefits and
marginal costs.

80AF0D9C38DC479FB3F7286E313CFA36.description:
The minimum efficient scale plays a role in
determining the concentration of firms in a
market and the market structure.

37D40EA9BFB84703B3B05B054FBD5FBE.description:
The long-run average total cost is characterized
by economies of scale, diseconomies of scale,
or constant returns to scale (efficient scale).

A343054AE0004CECBA0C214225CBA34D.description:
The relationship between inputs and outputs
in the long run is described by the scale
of production—increasing, decreasing, or
constant returns to scale.

DCE3939DB4D04C1A9117B1F40D269F14.description:
In the long run, firms can adjust all their inputs,
and as a result, all costs become variable.

607881B0C6DB412D930BE260B64CF3F3.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to production
and cost.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
production and cost are
related in the short run
and long run.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) the various
measures of productivity
and short-run and
long-run costs.

388FE01F253B462D9B86C925C80B414A.description:
Firms’ production and cost constraints over different input and output levels shape
optimal decisions in the short run and long run.

00D0DBDAEA8E44E6B35886C365EB0007.description:
Cost curves can shift in response to changes
in input costs and productivity.

8F71869CCE7249BB970C9161F0901BE1.description:
Specialization and the division of labor reduce
marginal costs for firms.

5C9C442E6B4E486992351429DEDA0FE0.description:
Production functions with diminishing marginal
returns yield an upward-sloping marginal
cost curve.

0D1480DCE32D4A839A23147A866F8BB5.description:
Marginal cost, average (fixed, variable, and
total) cost, total cost, and total variable cost
change as total output changes, but total fixed
cost remains constant at all output levels,
including zero output.

51F2883A1B8C4211932A2BE070BF69D9.description:
Fixed costs and variable costs determine the
total cost.

A3E05F570B904A1495C3CA5B4B7D0077.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to production
and cost.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
production and cost are
related in the short run
and long run.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) the various
measures of productivity
and short-run and
long-run costs.

5D73F9BC2B0A43109DC2A4DD9FCB0FE8.description:
Firms’ production and cost constraints over different input and output levels shape
optimal decisions in the short run and long run.

3D957074610144EE81F6C023DEE6AA51.description:
Diminishing marginal returns occur as the
firm employs more of one input, holding other
inputs constant, to produce a product (output)
in the short run.

86F0AD2959744369B920302308389FCE.description:
Marginal product and average product change
as input usage changes, and hence, total
product changes.

0A88853A0E0D46A2AF26A859E57C8CAE.description:
The production function explains the
relationship between inputs and outputs both
in the short run and the long run.

D4DCEF78E03341409036076B900E6BF0.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to production
and cost.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
production and cost are
related in the short run
and long run.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) the various
measures of productivity
and short-run and
long-run costs.

95B60875510A4B6AA7F894E5EB86C89F.description:
Firms’ production and cost constraints over different input and output levels shape
optimal decisions in the short run and long run.

79252AC2873E4FEF9BB46CC1E7C61D2B.description:
Production,
Cost, and
the Perfect
Competition
Model

BC9FB865AFBC486EB1D48DFEB7A40BA4.description:
Quotas can be used to alter quantities
produced and therefore affect price, consumer
surplus, and total economic surplus.

50DACF5D33924B4EA05330D0B6E7846E.description:
Tariffs, which governments sometimes use to
influence international trade, affect domestic
price, quantity, government revenue, and
consumer surplus and total economic surplus.

670A7521646D42668D1281802ACB2F71.description:
Equilibria in competitive markets may be
altered by the decision to open an economy
to trade with other countries; equilibrium price
can be higher or lower than under autarky, and
the gap between domestic supply and demand
is filled by trade. Opening an economy to trade
with other countries affects consumer surplus,
producer surplus, and total economic surplus.

133D219047944FDF8F0F473892C14B8F.description:
a. Define tariffs and quotas.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
markets are affected by
public policy related to
international trade.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from public policy related
to international trade.

CA897C22AB224DD9ACA7960770174D7D.description:
Government policies influence consumer and producer behavior and therefore
affect market outcomes.

0793C9A9A8AA41188832159CE525B57C.description:
The incidence of taxes and subsidies imposed on
goods traded in perfectly competitive markets
depends on the elasticity of supply and demand.

B47A38AC44B74A46BA8D901772E28723.description:
Deadweight loss represents the losses to
buyers and sellers as a result of government
intervention in an efficient market.

89CF87B5C8594B2EB491E506A1C30A78.description:
Government intervention in a market producing
the efficient quantity through taxes, subsidies,
price controls, or quantity controls can only
decrease allocative efficiency.

365F14075D894937A566599772C04153.description:
Taxes and subsidies affect government
revenues or costs.

EB211F41B34F4A2F9859E470F0EF6473.description:
Governments use taxes and subsidies to
change incentives in ways that influence
consumer and producer behavior, shifting the
supply and demand curves accordingly

2698DA3B90F845B48F1385F709B653EB.description:
Some government policies, such as price
floors, price ceilings, and other forms of price
and quantity regulation, affect incentives and
outcomes in all market structures.

492A916CCC8A46018E3E5DA14968A2F1.description:
a. Define forms of
government price and
quantity intervention.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
government policies alter
consumer and producer
behaviors that influence
incentives and therefore
affect outcomes.
c. Calculate (using data from
a graph or table where
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from government policies.

9068402A2D154A9E82352BEB185D58A4.description:
Government policies influence consumer and producer behavior and therefore
affect market outcomes.

C5082488CDAB4DD3A068B0D47AB3FE03.description:
The Effects of
Government
Intervention in Markets

E88E56E116F04F02845572442FF84E00.description:
Factors that shift the market demand and
market supply curves cause price, quantity,
consumer surplus, producer surplus, and
total economic surplus (within that market) to
change. The impact of the change depends on
the price elasticities of demand and supply.

DAB12A73A7094EBCA7D0B735A74F5077.description:
Whenever markets experience imbalances—
creating disequilibrium prices and quantities,
surpluses, and shortages—market forces drive
price and quantity toward equilibrium.

7A44CB1780864373ABF0860BC269CDDA.description:
a. Define a surplus
and shortage.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
changes in underlying
conditions and shocks
to a competitive market
can alter price, quantity,
consumer surplus, and
producer surplus.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes
in price, quantity,
consumer surplus, and
producer surplus in
response to changes
in market conditions or
market disequilibrium.

DF124716A09343EFA63ED6D1AE0527D2.description:
Although equilibria are stable, an economy can move from one equilibrium to
another if market conditions change.

4A5BF0A0E721489383C7956ED3FE0BCE.description:
Market Disequilibrium
and Changes in
Equilibrium

4ABAF14DD73A4A46B875676957187E97.description:
Market equilibrium maximizes total economic
surplus in the absence of market failures,
meaning that perfectly competitive markets
are efficient.

27F19871325A46DDA81FBB7D83BCEB77.description:
Economists use consumer surplus and
producer surplus to measure the benefits
markets create to buyers and sellers and
understand market efficiency

D6C00D6C7DC34AFEB47BFDF596494900.description:
Equilibrium price provides information
to economic decision-makers to guide
resource allocation.

1E09FAC835434A1F8A76CBD8A7E6AC78.description:
In a perfectly competitive market, equilibrium is
achieved (and markets clear with no shortages
or surpluses) when the price of a good or
service brings the quantity supplied and
quantity demanded into balance, in the sense
that buyers wish to purchase the same quantity
that sellers wish to provide.

8336CEE7B55945BAAECD509E683A407E.description:
The supply-demand model is a tool for
understanding what factors influence prices and
quantities and why prices and quantities might
differ across markets or change over time.

2CC33E9EC3674239A7DBEE060B99C3A4.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate)
market equilibrium,
consumer surplus, and
producer surplus.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how
equilibrium price, quantity,
consumer surplus,
and producer surplus
for a good or service
are determined.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
as appropriate) areas
of consumer surplus
and producer surplus
at equilibrium.

828D042AC6F847BEAA7BEF2C3BBC9030.description:
Although equilibria are stable, an economy can move from one equilibrium to
another if market conditions change.

4F988703848B43BE9FA16744BA7BC761.description:
Market Equilibrium
and Consumer and
Producer Surplus

A953F5B7E643428B960346DF88863333.description:
Cross-price elasticity of demand is measured
by the percentage change in the quantity
demanded of one good divided by the
percentage change in the price of another
good. Economists use the cross-price
elasticity of demand to determine whether
goods are substitutes, complements,
or not related.

21D2EC6DB63946ED913038624B1922C9.description:
Income elasticity of demand is measured
by the percentage change in the quantity
demanded divided by the percentage change
in consumers’ income. Economists use the
income elasticity of demand to determine
whether a good is normal or inferior.

A8F3A3883BF347F0B2E9E7F702FCA9B5.description:
Elasticity can be measured for any determinant
of demand or supply, not just the price.

4BE2A47D595645A388D3ABF4BED7BC31.description:
a. Define measures
of elasticity.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
measures of elasticity and
the impact of a given price
change on total revenue
or total expenditure.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or a table
as appropriate) measures
of elasticity

BE7A440BBE884EEABF112D036828328E.description: Individuals and firms respond to incentives and face constraints.

BB8EC768FC634B85BBFC37ABCC3B94C6.description:
The price elasticity of supply depends
on certain factors such as the price of
alternative inputs.

C7F07E82F0D34BEFACC2C717CF9EC229.description:
Ranges of values of elasticity of supply are
described as elastic or inelastic with the
separating benchmark being a magnitude of 1,
where the change in the price and the change
in the quantity supplied are proportional.
a. When the magnitude of the value of
elasticity is greater than 1, the supply is
described as being elastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
b. When the magnitude of the value of
elasticity is less than 1, the supply is
described as being inelastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
c. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity
is equal to 1, the supply is described as
being unit elastic with respect to that price in
the range of the given change.

977293A22DB047A08C7E941AA64B60DF.description:
Price elasticity of supply is measured by
the percentage change in quantity supplied
divided by the percentage change in price,
or the responsiveness of the quantity supplied
to changes in price.

486EEF5B74D24418A27A727BD963AEE9.description:
a. Define measures
of elasticity.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
measures of elasticity and
the impact of a given price
change on total revenue or
total expenditure.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or a table as
appropriate) measures
of elasticity

9FF40C6DB5ED49398D7144DAAC1D2FDC.description: Individuals and firms respond to incentives and face constraints.

4BA8EBE528C5461399E56BDDADA244EF.description:
The impact of a given price change on total
revenue or total expenditure will depend
on whether demand is elastic, inelastic, or
unit elastic.

BDF2C71AA2454D3586C0C6B5DC483616.description:
The price elasticity of demand depends
on certain factors such as the availability
of substitutes.

EFB9C50FA81846908D8C4B28494172D3.description:
Ranges of values of elasticity of demand are
described as elastic or inelastic with the
separating benchmark being a magnitude of 1,
where the change in the price and the change
in the quantity demanded are proportional.
a. When the magnitude of the value of
elasticity is greater than 1, the demand is
described as being elastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
b. When the magnitude of the value of
elasticity is less than 1, the demand is
described as being inelastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
c. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity
is equal to 1, the demand is described as
being unit elastic with respect to that price in
the range of the given change.

8E0EAC042EAA4DC68DB0B30EEECC5278.description:
Price elasticity of demand is measured by the
percentage change in quantity demanded
divided by the percentage change in price or
the responsiveness of the quantity demanded
to changes in price. Elasticity varies along
a linear demand curve, meaning slope is
not elasticity.

F306FF62006D42B48340296F404DE060.description:
Economists use the concept of elasticity
to measure the magnitude of percentage
changes in quantity owing to any given
changes in the own-price, income, and prices
of related goods.

D6EDDBE23CF14E948D2FA128ED3C57A0.description:
a. Define measures
of elasticity.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
measures of elasticity and
the impact of a given price
change on total revenue
or total expenditure.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or a table as
appropriate) measures
of elasticity.

76460049B18B403292255A56B67A035A.description: Individuals and firms respond to incentives and face constraints.

F59D5159F21742E5AA7C206591C5B0B4.description:
Changes in the determinants of supply can
cause the supply curve to shift.

A441AEA962A449328B09AB8F4D587B3E.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) producers’
(sellers’) responses
to changes in incentives
and technology.

E08B2E7A028C4E80B5ACE472DBA07AE9.description:
The market supply curve (schedule) is derived
from the summation of individual supply
curves (schedules). The market supply curve
is upward-sloping.

082F339658854845B1D71F19E92FEC48.description:
A change in own-price causes a change in
quantity supplied in the same direction and
a movement along a supply curve.

FB57C6704D2A474982F0FE75E6D480FE.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the law
of supply.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between price
and quantity supplied.

3F46B1333AA440208BFE28ADDB30E9F2.description: Individuals and firms respond to incentives and face constraints.

FDE5B062D05542749EA0A5FDF0BFE7B2.description:
Changes in the determinants of consumer
demand can cause the demand curve to shift.

778EEA2E115D4BB995456BF2C4B1B9B1.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) buyers’
responses to changes in
incentives and constraints.

1550ED7BA9FF42B18B8BDEF65A65ABD8.description:
The market demand curve (schedule) is derived
from the summation of individual demand
curves (schedules).

530B03FF339E4DE89D327723D6710958.description:
The conceptual relationship between price
and quantity stated by the law of demand leads
to downward-sloping demand curves explained
by the income effect and substitution effect
and/or by diminishing marginal utility.

88E30CCC6543459EB519789E43A5F419.description:
The law of demand suggests that a change in the
own-price causes a change in quantity demanded
in the opposite direction and a movement along a
demand (marginal benefit) curve.

BE440F6897874F72958F22B3EA23466C.description:
Individuals often respond to incentives, such
as those presented by prices, but also face
constraints, such as income, time, and legal
and regulatory frameworks.

01232A5E73114C7EA5C65EB4BCC36CC0.description:
A well-defined system of property rights is
necessary for the market system to function well.

58014EDA824540CA8F0736803EF4FFDD.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) key terms
and factors related to
consumer decision making
and the law of demand.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between price
and quantity demanded
and how buyers
respond to incentives
and constraints.

A2E8992E235C4A38853FA11E6F0BF7E3.description: Individuals and firms respond to incentives and face constraints.

122482144AD64026BDB802D95E54D40F.description:
The optimal quantity is achieved when
marginal benefit is equal to marginal cost
or where total benefit is maximized.

3BC5CE40783A4A03828920BCDBF4EFFC.description:
The optimal quantity at any point in time
does not depend on fixed costs (sunk costs)
or fixed benefits that have already been
determined by past choices.

B9FE4C5939334ECCACC657EB83A7B4FD.description:
Marginal analysis involves comparing the
additional benefit of increasing a given activity
with the additional cost. Comparing marginal
benefit (MB) with marginal cost (MC) helps
individuals (firms) decide whether to increase,
decrease, or maintain their consumption
(production) levels.

47E3754DD7B64CC0BC95B43FC56A7399.description:
a. Define marginal analysis
and related terms.
b. Explain a decision
using marginal analysis
(using a table or a graph
when appropriate).

BF71334A142E4E75AFDE014A76443BD4.description:
Consumers allocate their limited income
to purchase the combination of goods that
maximizes their utility by equating/comparing
the marginal utility of the last dollar spent
on each good.

1B15F5EB8DF044FEB98A20CEDA3C5C42.description:
Consumers experience diminishing
marginal utility in the consumption of goods
and services.

7D42E4B1D9DF4C17B7DE851EA8A5729B.description:
In a model of rational consumer choice,
consumers are assumed to make choices so
as to maximize their total utility.

3E4492AD069D4727A844CD48CF1A880F.description:
Consumers face constraints and have to
make optimal decisions accounting for
these constraints.

AD5C164B5B204327AFCC867FDAEEB19C.description:
a. Define the key assumptions
of consumer choice theory.
b. Explain (using a table
or graph as appropriate)
how a rational consumer’s
decision making
involves the use of
marginal benefits and
marginal costs.
c. Calculate (using a
table or a graph when
appropriate) how a rational
consumer’s decision
making involves the use
of marginal benefits
and marginal costs.

812DD32063ED4ADFBF171E71B92E113F.description:
To determine the optimal level at which to pursue an activity whose total benefits exceed
total cost, rational economic agents compare marginal benefits and marginal costs.

860F2AAFCE26479CB6FB3DDD918D3117.description:
Some decisions permit rational agents to look
at only marginal benefit and marginal cost.
Other decisions cannot be broken down into
increments in this way and must be evaluated
by looking at total benefits and total costs.

B01365D526D44BD4B0A50D9A4CE0F6CA.description:
Total net benefits, the difference between total
benefits and total costs, are maximized at the
optimal choice.

30814AEBB19449698BAA28078B7DE1A3.description:
a. Explain a decision by
comparing total benefits
and total costs (using
a table or a graph
when appropriate).
b. Calculate total benefits
and total costs (using
a table or graph
where appropriate).

4C6A063359874EDEBCE772756035BC72.description:
Total benefits form the metric “utility” for
consumers and total revenue for firms.

91BED41486B048A6A890278AC9CDA60B.description:
Rational agents consider opportunity costs,
whether implicit or explicit, when calculating
the total economic costs of any decision.

3C7C5D5AAFFC418A931A29949741C831.description:
a. Define opportunity cost.
b. Explain the opportunity
costs associated
with choices.
c. Calculate the opportunity
costs associated
with choices.

8B094DDD2B8B4F678FCACD6792E853EC.description: Rational economic decisions require the evaluation of costs and benefits.

265362D34810474DB2FEA743F012F742.description:
Comparative advantage and opportunity
costs determine the terms of trade for
exchange under which mutually beneficial
trade can occur.

2F7BE86FF98748AFA8BAB277E652382B.description:
Production specialization according
to comparative advantage, not absolute
advantage, results in exchange opportunities
that lead to consumption possibilities
beyond the PPC.

E59F736BA6B84D06A911CCFA4079EBF7.description:
a. Explain (using data
from PPCs or tables
as appropriate) how
specialization according
to comparative advantage
with appropriate
terms of trade can lead
to gains from trade.
b. Calculate (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) mutually
beneficial terms of trade.

FD6C4686EA1D42C1AA56EB4CAC8B5FE6.description:
Comparative advantage describes a situation
in which an individual, business, or country
can produce a good or service at a lower
opportunity cost than another producer.

FEEF7983B3CA4EC8A6418A2B99F31B2B.description:
Absolute advantage describes a situation
in which an individual, business, or country
can produce more of a good or service than
any other producer with the same quantity
of resources.

1EC7C8D2E8A2449DAE16C901B1307FDF.description:
a. Define absolute advantage
and comparative
advantage.
b. Determine (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) absolute and
comparative advantage.

0F358053D6654B1084CDE6EF198DB642.description:
The consequences of scarcity can be mitigated through specialization in production
and by exchange.

1413616EFB654E7DA3813BE7E2B76928.description:
Economic growth results in an outward shift
of the PPC.

7815F0F3376D40DA8DC6EFC68F6E5551.description:
The PPC can shift due to changes in
factors of production as well as changes in
productivity/technology

B096BCB1EBC043669AAE980ACF6F498D.description:
The shape of the PPC depends on whether
opportunity costs are constant, increasing,
or decreasing.

A7694EA3EE1C44D086319A359956C27B.description:
The PPC can be used to illustrate the concepts
of scarcity, opportunity cost, efficiency,
underutilized resources, and economic growth
or contraction.

E2C0944CA5604E49B05701D39EC58EEB.description:
The PPC is a model used to show the trade-offs
associated with allocating resources.

95FC8F747392479491FD22E72C64578A.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
production possibilities
curve (PPC) and
related terms.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how the
production possibilities
curve (PPC) illustrates
opportunity costs,
trade-offs, inefficiency,
efficiency, and economic
growth or contraction
under various conditions.
c. Calculate (using
data from PPCs or
tables as appropriate)
opportunity cost.

1146FE1417B2474D8BDBD3C2E70C87AF.description:
Most resources are scarce, and in most cases the use of resources involves
constraints and trade-offs.

268DD792922444E28984B19BCCEA478D.description:
Resource allocation is significantly influenced
by the economic system adopted by society,
such as command economy, market economy,
or mixed economy. Each system involves a
particular set of institutional arrangements and
a coordinating mechanism for allocating scarce
resources and distributing output.

A525908A102E4D8589E19D6FD062B576.description:
Resource allocation involves answering three
basic questions: What goods and services to
produce? How to produce those goods and
services? And who consumes those goods
and services?

3F658D65DADF4247A53328CFAC12D155.description:
Define how resource
allocation is influenced
by the economic system
adopted by society.

413B01D5E3E545C98D53C0F6CEC44CB7.description:
Most resources are scarce, and in most cases the use of resources involves
constraints and trade-offs.

44F248AAC4BC4E1B90476A066A01E02C.description:
Most factors of production (such as land, labor,
and capital) are scarce, but some factors of
production (such as established knowledge)
may not be scarce due to their non-rival nature.

49CB3B1FA8924139A059EA3769C65E9C.description:
Economic trade-offs arise from the lack of
sufficient resources (scarcity) to meet society’s
wants and needs.

2A3652F66E20412F9D95E50DFB4EF220.description:
Define resources and the
cause(s) of their scarcity.

B2FFADC1D9A04E7B87D34967E0DA343F.description:
Most resources are scarce, and in most cases the use of resources involves
constraints and trade-offs.
